page.title: 08ST.JAMES' CATHOLIC CHURCH
page.content: In 1885,an iron church or "Tin Tabernacle" was erected for Catholics on the site where St.James' now stands. In 1909 it was hauled away in sections by a steam traction engine and replaced by the present stone church. Although described as being "in the Lombardic style" St.James' is, in fact, in no style at all,save that of a small Scottish Church.The little spire imitates the taller spire of St. Salvator's College Chapel which dominates St.Andrews' skyline. An attractive statue of the Virgin and Child is sited under the West gable and a staircase turret and baptistry jut out of the Western facade.Inside, the church is divided into three sections- nave, sanctuary and apse.The marble interior gives an Italian rather than a Scottish air to th Church.
